Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: From the QCD Flux Tubes to Black Holes and Back
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Sergey Dubovskiy at the New York University.

Effective field theory has proven to be an extremely successful and powerful framework for describing a wide range of phenomena from particle collisions at the Large Hadron Collider to the growth of density perturbations in cosmic fluids. However, it is challenged by two dramatic breakdowns of dimensional analysis---the incredible smallness of the vacuum energy and of the Higgs mass, compared to the characteristic scale of gravity. With the hope of helping to resolve these puzzles, Professor Dubovskiy aims to enrich the effective field theory toolbox with new sophisticated techniques and to come up with and test new radical theoretical ideas beyond the traditional framework. At the same time he will be looking for new observational probes, which may provide new hints on the origin of the Higgs mass and the vacuum energy. The research of Professor Dubovskiy will cover a broad spectrum of physical phenomena, ranging from the superradiant instability of astrophysical black holes as a tool to discover new particles to the dynamics of flux tubes, responsible for the confinement of quarks.

The research that will be funded covers not only a wide range of topics in high energy theory and cosmology, but has an impact throughout the Physics Division. For example, studies of the vacuum structure of string theory has led Prof. Dubovskiy to propose a new type of particle related to the axion, which would constitute the dark matter. Studying the interactions of this dark matter with black holes has led to extraordinary experimental signatures, ranging from astrophysical studies of black hole masses to specific gravitational wave signatures that are in the range accessible to the Advanced Large Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO). These will be studied in detail. There are also substantial interrelations with atomic physics and with nuclear physics. One of the other projects will contribute to understanding the dynamics of flux tubes, which hold quarks together in the nucleon.

The award will also fund community outreach activities. Professor Dubovskiy will contribute to the development of the NYU Science Communication Workshop program, which helps train a generation of scientists in effective communication with the public, and the award will support numerous scientists. He also will give presentations on particle physics and cosmology at a local high school. In addition, the research project relies on the active involvement of graduate students and postdocs, thereby bringing junior physicists to the frontiers of fundamental physics research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Strongly interacting particles, called hadrons (such as protons, mesons and glueballs), are build up of elementary consituents---quarks and gluons. The latter carry "color", which is a generalization of more familiar electric charge. However, colored quarks and gluons never observed as free particles in Nature, instead they are always found inside colorless hadrons. This remarkable phenomenon called color confinement. 

Confinement arises as a consequence of string formation between colored particle. This string is also called "flux tube", because it is build up of the colored generalization of the conventional electric field flux. The main goal of this project was to study dynamical properties of the confining strings using theoretical tools and numerical simulations. Apart from direct applications to strong interactions, this question is important also because string dynamics is described by an emergent gravitional theory. Thus this setup provides a rare window into quantum gravitational dynamics. Of course, unlike in realistic gravity, here one is dealing with a gravitational theory with a single spatial dimension (direction along the string). Still, there are good chances that the lessons learned from this study will provide helpful universally applicable insights into puzzles of quantum gravity.

As a result of this project a universal proposal (dubbed Axionic String Ansatz (ASA)) for the gravitational theory describing high energy asymptotics of the confining string has been put forward. This proposal applies in a realistic theory with three spatial dimensions, but also for simpler models with two or one spatial dimensions. Based on the ASA a prediction has been made for the quantum numbers and the structure of the mass spectrum of glueballs in a model of strong interactions with two spatial dimensions. These predictions have been tested via computer Monte-Carlo simulations. As a result, a perfect agreement has been found for 39 lightest glueball states, thus providing a strong confirmation of the ASA.

As far as the relation to gravity goes, as a result of this project it was shown that the gravitational theory arising in the ASA is a version of the well-known Jackiw--Teitelboim gravity. Remarkably, it turned out possible to obtain an exact description of scattering in this theory, as well as of its finite volume energy spectrum. Surprisingly, this reproduced the results obtained recently in the studies of a qualitateively new kind of quantum field theories, which became known as a TT-deformation. TT-deformation attracted a lot of attention recently, and results obtained in this project provided a crucial insight in its nature and properties.

Furthermore, in the course of the project it was argued that scattering on the worldsheet of confining strings provide a simple model of black hole complementarity. This model provides a promising setup to study fundamental puzzles associated with black hole physics in quantum gravity.
